contentfulBlogPost.title: Federal COVID Data in a Single Stream

childMarkdownRemark.html: Zach Lipton is a San Francisco software developer and Data Infrastructure co-lead for the COVID Tracking Project.
Dave Luo has an MD/MBA and is a Data Science and Data Viz lead at The COVID Tracking Project.
Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

description.description: We’ve created a bit of code that helps combine federal testing, case, deaths, and hospitalization data into a single spreadsheet.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Kara Schechtman is Data Quality Co-Lead for The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Federal COVID-19 Testing Data Is Getting Better

lede.lede: The federal government improved its state and county-level COVID-19 PCR testing data since we analyzed it in February. Here’s an update on those changes and what we hope to see next for the data.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Alice Goldfarb leads The COVID Tracking Project’s part in The COVID Racial Data Tracker, and is a Nieman Visiting Fellow.

blog_post.title: Federal COVID Data 101: What We Know About Race and Ethnicity Data

lede.lede: Publicly available federal race and ethnicity COVID-19 data is currently usable and improving, although it shares many of the problems we’ve found in state-reported data.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.
Jessica Malaty Rivera has an MS in Emerging Infectious Diseases and is the Science Communication Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: How Not to Interpret COVID-19 Data

lede.lede: Beware of dating schemes, data dumps, weather events and other issues that can lead to mistakes that confuse the public.

childMarkdownRemark.html: The COVID Tracking Project is a volunteer organization launched from The Atlantic and dedicated to collecting and publishing the data required to understand the COVID-19 outbreak in the United States.

blog_post.title: Federal COVID Data 101: How to Find Data

lede.lede: Here’s where and how you can find COVID-19 data now that The COVID Tracking Project has ended.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Zach Lipton is a San Francisco software developer and Data Infrastructure co-lead for the COVID Tracking Project.
Dave Luo has an MD/MBA and is a Data Science and Data Viz lead at The COVID Tracking Project.
Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Federal COVID Data in a Single Stream

lede.lede: We’ve created a bit of code that helps combine federal testing, case, deaths, and hospitalization data into a single spreadsheet.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Dave Luo has an MD/MBA and is a Data Science and Data Viz lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

Catherine Pollack is a third year PhD candidate in the Quantitative Biomedical Sciences program at Dartmouth College. Her dissertation research combines data science, epidemiology, and public policy to combat online health misinformation.

blog_post.title: Federal COVID Data 101: Working with Hospitalization Numbers

lede.lede: Here’s a walkthrough of the Department of Health and Human Services’ dataset and what you should know about it.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Jennifer Clyde is a data quality and data entry shift lead at the COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Federal COVID Data 101: Working with Case Data

lede.lede: Here’s a walkthrough of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) daily case dataset and what you should know about it.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.

blog_post.title: Where to Find Simple COVID-19 Data for the US

lede.lede: As The COVID Tracking Project approaches its final day of data compilation on March 7, 2021, we are recommending a selection of federal data sources to people who want a quick and easy way to keep an eye on the pandemic.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Joseph Bensimon is a member of the COVID Tracking Project’s Data Quality team.
Quang P. Nguyen is a PhD candidate in the Department of Epidemiology at Dartmouth College.

blog_post.title: Federal COVID Data 101: Working with Death Numbers

lede.lede: The CDC provides two different datasets regarding COVID-19 fatalities. Here’s a walkthrough of how they compare to each other and to The COVID Tracking Project’s data.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Artis Curiskis is outreach & reporting co-lead at the COVID Tracking Project and collaboratively runs the CTP special projects Long-Term Care COVID Tracker and City Data.
Kara Oehler is outreach & reporting co-lead at the COVID Tracking Project and collaboratively runs the CTP special projects Long-Term Care COVID Tracker and City Data.
Aarushi Sahejpal is a Shift Lead on Long-Term Care and City Data at the COVID Tracking Project. She also studies International Relations & Data Science at American University
Dave Luo has an MD/MBA and is a Data Science and Data Viz lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Federal COVID Data 101: Working with CMS Nursing Home Data

lede.lede: Here’s what we know about the only federal dataset on COVID-19 outcomes in long-term care facilities.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Kara Schechtman is Data Quality Co-Lead for The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Federal COVID Data 101: Working with Testing Data

lede.lede: At least three different federal agencies share testing data for SARS-CoV-2 in at least four different places. Here’s a little about where that data comes from, what each dataset has to offer, and how you can use the datasets best in light of their large differences from state-provided data.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Rachel Glickhouse is a New York-based journalist who works on project management and impact tracking at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Learn More About Using Federal COVID-19 Data with The COVID Tracking Project

lede.lede: In February and March, we’ll hold a series of free trainings to help anyone who uses our data to understand existing federal numbers.

Here are a few examples of what’s possible:","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"B7TkicS4qhUvQhDJI3Orw","type":"Link","linkType":"Entry"}}},"content":[],"nodeType":"embedded-entry-block"},{"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"6WTU2PMUcDFInQFchAl8C8","type":"Link","linkType":"Entry"}}},"content":[],"nodeType":"embedded-entry-block"},{"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"3RZIR2M2aiAvUjT5u1dhvJ","type":"Link","linkType":"Entry"}}},"content":[],"nodeType":"embedded-entry-block"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Notes and caveats","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"heading-2"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"In the federal case and death dataset, New York and New York City are given as separate entities. We have summed them into one to match the other federal datasets. To disable this feature, set the ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"code"}],"value":"COMBINE_NY_NYC","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" flag to ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"code"}],"value":"False","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"value":" ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"in the code.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"list-item"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Federal testing data data is incomplete for the most recent days, and therefore usually shows a steep drop in testing. This is due to a backfill process which assigns the tests to the date at which they were performed (whenever possible). This is in contrast to CTP’s testing data, which was arranged by date of public report. Assigning tests to the date of test specimen collection is more epidemiologically correct but takes more time and effort to prepare and revise. Be cautious in interpreting data for the most recent 3-5 testing days, as it will contain a reporting artifact of steeply dropping test numbers due to the method of assigning tests to the date they were performed. You may also spot changes to the timeseries in prior months, as tests are precisely backfilled to their original collection dates when possible.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"list-item"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Users should keep an eye out for new notes on data and schema changes in the ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://beta.healthdata.gov/National/COVID-19-Community-Profile-Report/gqxm-d9w9"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"Community Profile Reports","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" as these may change over time. In the \"User Notes\" tab, visit “High-Visibility Data Notes” and “Recent Changes”; in the \"Date Notes\" tab, visit the “Dynamic Data Notes” section.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"list-item"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"The dating schemes for the various data points (tests, cases, etc.) can be subtly different. Please read our ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://covidtracking.com/analysis-updates/federal-covid-data-101-how-to-find-data"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"Federal 101 series","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" for more detailed information.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"list-item"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Federal hospitalization data contains two distinct patient types: confirmed and suspected COVID-19 patients. Both metrics are important.  However, our state-level data was a mix of these two types as states varied in their reporting: some reported only confirmed, others combined confirmed plus suspected, while still others used another definition of hospitalized COVID-19 patients. It is therefore difficult to create a one-to-one match between our currently hospitalized figures and those from the federal data. See our ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://covidtracking.com/analysis-updates/covid-data-101-working-with-hospitalization-numbers"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"Hospitalization Data 101 post","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" for a state-by-state comparison between the state metrics and the federal data.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"list-item"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Federal hospitalization data started to become much more complete and broader in scope after July 15, 2020 when the daily reporting system used by hospitals switched to HHS Protect and reporting of most fields became mandatory. Incomplete, voluntarily reported hospitalization data before July 15th does exist in the federal data file and comes from CDC’s National Healthcare Safety Network (NHSN) system. We advise caution when interpreting hospitalization trends from earlier in the pandemic when hospital reporting was less complete. See the ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://protect-public.hhs.gov/pages/hospital-reporting"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"HHS Protect Public Data Hub page","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" on hospital reporting for granular details on the current completeness of hospitalization data down to the individual facility-level and ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://beta.healthdata.gov/stories/s/vwaj-ban6"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"how that reporting has improved over time","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":". We have proactively removed all hospitalization data before July 15th from the above file, but you can modify the script to include all available data points.  ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"list-item"}],"nodeType":"unordered-list"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

references.caption: A recreation of the standard COVID Tracking Project 4-pane visualization. In this example, we have removed testing data and added in hospital admissions in its place (see notes below).

image.title: 4 daily charts using CDC data
image.description: 4 daily charts showing key COVID-19 metrics for the US over time (Cases, Hospitalized, Hospital Admissions, and Deaths). All 4 charts are trending downward, though cases at a slower rate than in prior weeks.

references.caption: A cartogram of US states showing the confirmed and suspected COVID-19 hospitalizations per million people.

image.title: Cartogram with CDC data
image.description: US cartogram showing the number of confirmed + suspected hospitalized COVID-19 patients per million people by state. No state is over 308 hospitalized per million as of Mar 3rd.

references.caption: A set of bar charts showing COVID-19 deaths over time for each major US region. Note that the federal data set does contain major backlog spikes when states report old deaths on a single day.

image.title: 4 daily charts with CDC death data
image.description: 4 daily bar charts with 7-day average line overlaid showing COVID-19 deaths in each major US region. Deaths are trending down in all regions (with some wobbles in the South due to inconsistent reporting).

lede.lede: We’ve created a bit of code that helps combine federal testing, case, deaths, and hospitalization data into a single spreadsheet.
